instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Hello, I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that came in dead, looks clean no liquid damage. It had a short on PPBUS. after injecting power (removed all FDMF chips) I found a short on <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>, replaced it and now I have 13.07 on both sides of F7000. On L7030 I get fluctuation from 8.4-8.6v but there is no short. On charger I get 20V, 0.04A. Not sure what to check next. Could it be CPU already died from short before?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Very likely dead CPU.
Injected voltage goes directly into CPU, through <SIGNAL>1V0_SUS</SIGNAL>.
Do NOT do this ever again!!!
So many times explained WHY NOT in the forum, and people still doing this :(.

CPU could be already fried because of shorted <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> (on high-side part).
But you've eliminated the lowest chance of being still good...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Hello, I have been in the forum before but lost my login details. 

From what I understood is that if I remove all high-side mosfets I could inject voltage? How would you suggest to find a short on PPBUS otherwise if board is completely clean? Is there anyway we can measure resistance to see if the CPU is dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: If you get the same ohm value (to ground) on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and one big coil (not only from CPU), guess what that means???
